title: Static relative jumps and calls for the EVM
description: Introduce five EVM instructions (RJUMP, RJUMPI, RJUMPV, RJUMPSUB, RJUMPSUBV) that encode destinations as signed immediates, replacing most dynamic JUMP patterns and enabling cheaper, more easily validated control flow.
author: Greg Colvin, Alex Beregszaszi, Andrei Maiboroda, Pawe≈Ç Bylica
laymanDescription: Adds five new EVM jump/call instructions that point to nearby code using a small offset instead of a pushed address, making contracts cheaper to run and easier for clients and tools to verify after Glamsterdam.

endUsers.description: May see lower gas from contracts using static jumps; no direct action or UX impact.

appDevs.description: Need to emit five new RJUMP opcodes to gain cost/perf; requires building for Glamsterdam EVM and EIP-7979.

walletDevs.description: Update opcode tables and simulators so bytecode with RJUMP* disassembles and estimates gas correctly; minimal runtime changes.

toolingInfra.description: Static analyzers, tracers, bytecode validators must understand relative offset encoding and extended checks from EIP-7979.

layer2s.description: L2s implementing Glamsterdam EVM need the same five opcodes and validation or contracts using them cannot deploy.

stakersNodes.description: Validators must run updated EL clients for Glamsterdam; failure to upgrade will lead to consensus failures on new blocks.

clClients.description: Complexity limited to fork configuration and Engine API versioning so EL can announce support for new opcodes.

elClients.description: Must add RJUMP, RJUMPI, RJUMPV, RJUMPSUB, RJUMPSUBV decoding, immediate validation, gas accounting, and tests extending EIP-7979.

benefits: Cheaper structured control flow than PUSHn+JUMP.
Improves static analysis by fixing jump targets.
Reduces runtime destination checks and gas.
Aligns with EOF/EIP-7979 validation for immediates.
